text: Family Member: You’re talking about placebo? Doctor: Yeah. So there is a two out of three chance that you will have a chance to get that medication. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: If, if I need that medication, I could though? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow.

text: Patient: Yeah. That does help. Family Member 1: So, okay. Family Member 2: So how many milligrams of that could he take? Family Member 1: Like 10? text: Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes. Doctor: and that almost yielded nothing either. You had like one abnormality at zero point one percent as in I don’t think you have much floating around which is kind of good but nothing that we can sort of target. Patient: Yeah, Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, we got a target something? Doctor: Well, I think we… Patient: Got to find out if we…

Doctor: So the chances of that helping the – the other part is a lot of these new treatments like the Xofigo for instance, the radiation, it doesn’t make the PSA go down. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m not exactly sure when that will happen. But it accelerates and that happens sooner. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
